node.title: Some questions about external_petsc_problem 2.0?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Still the question about this part \modules\external_petsc_solver\test\tests\external_petsc_problem\moose_as_parent.i
Q2: What makes the Picard iteration? What's the meaning of the Picard residual in the moose_as_parent.i and petsc_transient_as_sub.i?
When I run moose_as_parent.i, it will execute following these steps
Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 0.2
Beginning fixed point iteration 0
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 1
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 2
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...

Time Step 2, time = 0.4
Beginning fixed point iteration 0
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 1
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 2
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...

Time Step 3, time = 0.6
Beginning fixed point iteration 0
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 1
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
Beginning fixed point iteration 2
sub_app0: ...
Main app solve::...
Picard:...
....................................

Certainly, I find the external solve must be conducted by void ExternalPETScProblem::externalSolve().
But what conducts the Picard iteration? Is it from void ExternalPETScProblem::advanceState() ? Also, it seems that there is no data transfer from MOOSE to external solver in this example. In other words, the condition of the start for each time step of the external solver only following its way and does not have any relation with MOOSE main solver, so why does it need Picard iteration? What's the meaning of the residual of the Picard iteration?

Hello
The fixed point iterations are performed by the FixedPointSolve class.
You can see that when executing the moose_as_parent.i input file, you use a Transient executioner

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 10
  dt = 0.2

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  fixed_point_max_its = 10
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-8
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-9
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-12

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

because of the fixed_point parameters that were passed, a FixedPointSolve class is created to wrap both the MultiApps and the FEProblemSolve (the default solve for this input file) in a fixed point iteration

Also, it seems that there is no data transfer from MOOSE to external solver in this example. In other words, the condition of the start for each time step of the external solver only following its way and does not have any relation with MOOSE main solver, so why does it need Picard iteration?
You're right there is no Transfers to the child app in this input file
Thus it does not need a Picard iteration.


What's the meaning of the residual of the Picard iteration?

It's the nonlinear residual of the parent app. Here it decreases every time the solver is called. The first time it is called, it only converged to the requested tolerance   nl_rel_tol = 1e-6 then the next time it's uses the updated v field and converges firther, on the 3rd solve it is already tight and the v field does not change again, so  that's why the residual is very small

Is this your meaning for every time step?
Sub is executed in the beginning.
First in parent, it uses v = 0 or v from the previous time step .
Second in parent, it uses v from the next time step.
Third in parent, the v does not change.
But if this is true, the first, second, and third cut a time step into 3 parts? Actually they do not represent the full time step?

Sub is executed in the beginning.

TransientMultiApp is executed on TIMESTEP_BEGIN by default.
But that's not what you show here. It should be:

sub executes
data transferred to main
main executes
sub executes
data transferred to main
main executes with a tigther convergence

you can just look at the output log on the console, it shows that

Time Step 1, time = 0.2, dt = 0.2
Initial fixed point residual norm: 3.316625e+00

Beginning fixed point iteration 0

sub_app0: 
sub_app0: Time Step 1, time = 0.2, dt = 0.2
sub_app0: syncSolutions to external petsc App 
sub_app0: PETSc External Solve!
0 TS dt 0.2 time 0.
    0 SNES Function norm 7.215811749992e+02
      0 KSP Residual norm 1.812600607724e+00
      1 KSP Residual norm 3.184000953610e-01
      2 KSP Residual norm 1.109782762250e-01
      3 KSP Residual norm 4.774287620076e-02
      4 KSP Residual norm 1.066119625877e-02
      5 KSP Residual norm 1.905636433419e-03
      6 KSP Residual norm 2.071925087269e-04
      7 KSP Residual norm 4.123842437916e-05
      8 KSP Residual norm 9.426200921053e-06
    1 SNES Function norm 3.009696552534e-03
      0 KSP Residual norm 9.426200920969e-06
      1 KSP Residual norm 2.660932951319e-06
      2 KSP Residual norm 6.542299529123e-07
      3 KSP Residual norm 8.976376835224e-08
      4 KSP Residual norm 1.929475978757e-08
      5 KSP Residual norm 8.631984111349e-09
      6 KSP Residual norm 2.470485970064e-09
      7 KSP Residual norm 4.240939651349e-10
      8 KSP Residual norm 6.723165717722e-11
    2 SNES Function norm 2.268243483623e-08
1 TS dt 0.2 time 0.2
sub_app0: syncSolutions from external petsc App
sub_app0:  Solve Converged!
Fixed point residual norm after TIMESTEP_BEGIN MultiApps: 1.951095e+01

Main app solve:
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.969494e+01
      0 Linear |R| = 1.969494e+01
      1 Linear |R| = 1.574952e+00
      2 Linear |R| = 2.764162e-02
      3 Linear |R| = 3.807315e-04
      4 Linear |R| = 5.703901e-06
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 1.007532e-05
 Solve Converged!

 0 Picard |R| = 3.316625e+00
 1 Picard |R| = 1.951095e+01


But if this is true, the first, second, and third cut a time step into 3 parts? Actually they do not represent the full time step?

No the time step is not cut. It's just the same time step taken several times, with just a tighter convergence criterion every time. It's because it relies on a loose relative convergence, so every execution is relative to the residual achieved on the previous solve

Yes the figure is accurate
see similar things here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/presentation/index.html#/4/6

And the meaning of the picard |R|: just non-liner residual for the main...

yes. We are upgrading this soon using a new Convergence system which will allow us to define arbitrary convergence criteria

node.title: Could Not Apply Periodic Boundary when Using inp File
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi Moose Team,
I am trying to apply periodic boundary conditions to an .inp file. I have already set the node sets in Abaqus for each boundary. However, when I tried to apply the PBC to the model, the results showed the PBC was not applied and the variables were inconsistent at the PBC.
Here is the periodic boundary:
[./Periodic]
    [./auto_boundary_x]
      variable = disp_x
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-2 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_boundary_y]
      variable = disp_y
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-2 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_pos_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_pos_1
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-2 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_neg_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_neg_1
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-2 0.0 0.0'
    [../]
  [../]

And here is the inp file.
c1m1_H0002.zip
I am not sure why I could not apply the PBC, could you please help me figure out the problems?
Best and Thanks,

Hello
The offset should be 3.464e-3 not 3.464e-2
Guillaume

Sorry, I made a mistake. This is not the one I used for this model. Here is the code:
[./Periodic]
    [./auto_boundary_x]
      variable = disp_x
      primary = '4'
    secondary = '5'
    translation = '0.00346400007 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_boundary_y]
      variable = disp_y
      primary = '4'
    secondary = '5'
    translation = '0.00346400007 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_pos_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_pos_1
      primary = '4'
    secondary = '5'
    translation = '0.00346400007 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_neg_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_neg_1
      primary = '4'
    secondary = '5'
    translation = '0.00346400007 0.0 0.0'
    [../]
  [../]

I've tried both the 0.00346400007 and 3.464e-3, but it seems that the PBC is not applied to the model

in paraview I have a different numbering than you have
    [./auto_boundary_x]
      variable = disp_x
      primary = '4'
    secondary = '5'

should be
      primary = '3'
    secondary = '2'

considering the offset is positive.
We recommend you use names instead of ids

I used the names and ran the case again, but the results showed that the variables rho_edge_pos_1 and rho_edge_neg_1 are not consistent at the periodic boundary as shown in figure below.

Here is the code for PBC
  [./Periodic]
    [./auto_boundary_x]
      variable = disp_x
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-3 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_boundary_y]
      variable = disp_y
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-3 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_pos_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_pos_1
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-3 0.0 0.0'
    [../]

    [./auto_rho_edge_neg_boundary_x_1]
      variable = rho_edge_neg_1
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
    secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
    translation = '3.464e-3 0.0 0.0'
    [../]
  [../]

can we see the rest of the input?
PBCs can be finicky. You should make sure the nodes exactly line up on both sides.
I wonder if we actually support PBCs with displaced meshes, though in this case the displacement is periodic too so it should not be an issue

Here is the code
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [read]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = c1m1_H0002.inp
  []
[]


[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    order = FIRST
      family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [disp_y]
    order = FIRST
      family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [rho_edge_pos_1]
    initial_condition = 5.e7
    block = '1'
  []
  [rho_edge_neg_1]
    initial_condition = 5.e7
    block = '1'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./pk2]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = '1'
  [../]
  [./fp_xy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = '1'
  [../]
  [./exy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = '1'
  [../]
  [./slip_increment]
   order = CONSTANT
   family = MONOMIAL
   block = '1'
  [../]
  [./dislo_velocity]
   order = CONSTANT
   family = MONOMIAL
   block = '1'
  [../]
  [./epeq]
   order = CONSTANT
   family = MONOMIAL
   block = '1'
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [disp_load]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0.0 2.0  4.0'
    y = '0.0 0.00002 0.0'
  []
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  generate_output = 'stress_xy'
  additional_generate_output = 'strain_xy'
[]

[Kernels]

  [Edeg_Pos_Time_Deri_1]
    type = MassLumpedTimeDerivative
    variable = rho_edge_pos_1
  []
  [Edge_Pos_Flux_1]
    implicit = false
    type = ConservativeAdvectionSchmidNoSSD
    variable = rho_edge_pos_1
    upwinding_type = full
      dislo_sign = positive
      slip_sys_index = 0
      dislo_character = edge
  []

  [Edeg_Neg_Time_Deri_1]
    type = MassLumpedTimeDerivative
    variable = rho_edge_neg_1

    variable = rho_edge_neg_1

      dislo_sign = negative
      slip_sys_index = 0
      dislo_character = edge
  []

[]

[DGKernels]

  [dg_edge_pos_1]
    implicit = false
    type = DGAdvectionCoupled
    variable = rho_edge_pos_1
      dislo_character = edge
      dislo_sign = positive
      slip_sys_index = 0
  []

  [dg_edge_neg_1]
    implicit = false
    type = DGAdvectionCoupled
    variable = rho_edge_neg_1
      dislo_character = edge
      dislo_sign = negative
      slip_sys_index = 0
  []

[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./pk2]
   type = RankTwoAux
   variable = pk2
   rank_two_tensor = second_piola_kirchhoff_stress
   index_j = 0

   execute_on = timestep_end
   block = '1'
  [../]

    type = RankTwoAux

  [../]
  [./slip_inc]

  [../]
  [./dislo_vel]
   type = MaterialStdVectorAux

  [../]
  [./epeq]
   type = MaterialRealAux
   variable = epeq
   property = accumulated_equivalent_plastic_strain
   execute_on = timestep_end
   block = '1'
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    implicit = false
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
    C_ijkl = '1.129e5 0.664e5 0.664e5 1.129e5 0.664e5 1.129e5 0.279e5 0.279e5 0.279e5'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_1 = 0.0
    euler_angle_2 = 0.0 
    euler_angle_3 = 0.0 
    block = '1'
  [../]
  [./stress]
    implicit = false

    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'

  [../]
  [./trial_xtalpl]
    implicit = false

    number_slip_systems = 1

      w1 = 0.0

  [../]
  #new
  [./elasticity_tensor_hard]

  [../]

[]

[BCs]

    execute_on = final

This input file is for dg. I can provide another version without the dg kernels. Actually, in both dg or without dg cases, the PBCs are not applied properly.

I tested the input file without the dg kernels and turned the mesh file from inp to exodus file. The results showed the same problems: the PBCs were not applied properly. Also, I checked the node sets of the periodic boundary and ensured that the positions of the two boundary nodes corresponded one-to-one, but the nodes in the boundary set were not arranged in order. Should I arrange these nodes in order from bottom to top?

If the PBCs are applied correctly, the dislocation velocity should be consistent at the boundary. I tried different node sets but the PBCs were not applied properly. I wonder if the mesh file such as the inp from Abaqus is supported for the PBC. I would like to ensure whether the auto_direction in PBC supported by the inp file.

@FanZhangchen can you share a MOOSE-only input file showing the failure?
I dont have DGAdvectionCoupled or ConservativeAdvectionSchmidNoSSD or CrystalPlasticityBussoUpdate on my machine
Did you verify whether the PBCs work with an implicit time stepper?

Should I arrange these nodes in order from bottom to top?

no need for that

I dug into this and the PBCs are not triggering on this mesh.
I think the automatic detection (which I ended up trying to use instead of the translation) relies on sidesets. Anyway, use this Mesh block and this syntax for the PBCs
[Mesh]
    [read]
      type = FileMeshGenerator
      file = c1m1_H0002.inp
    []
    [separate]
      type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
      input = 'read'
      include_subdomains = '1'
      combinatorial_geometry = 'x > 0.002'
      new_subdomain = '2'
      block_id = 2
    []
    [remove]
      type = BoundaryDeletionGenerator
      input = 'separate'
      boundary_names = 'C1M1-1_BL-Elasticity C1M1-1_BL-Plasticity'
    []
    [create_sideset]
      type = SideSetsFromNodeSetsGenerator
      input = remove
    []
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'

[]

PBCs
[BCs]
  [Periodic]
    [auto_boundary_x]
      variable = disp_x
      primary = 'c1m1-1_pb_left'
      secondary = 'c1m1-1_pb_right'
      # translation = '3.464e-3 0.0 0.0'
      auto_direction = 'x'
    []
   ...

I have verified the PBCs with an implicit time stepper, but it doesn't work. I used the mesh block you provided, but it gave some errors. Could you tell me why I need to remove the C1M1-1_BL-Elasticity and C1M1-1_BL-Plasticity? These sets are for the block to distinguish different materials. Here is the info on the error.
*** ERROR ***
Periodic boundary neighbor not found

Could you tell me why I need to remove the C1M1-1_BL-Elasticity and C1M1-1_BL-Plasticity?

This is to help the automated periodic boundary condition detection, which should only see 1 sideset per boundary to pair with another boundary

These sets are for the block to distinguish different materials.

Materials are assigned to subdomains in moose, not nodesets. So the two sets are not helping you do that. You have the right subdomains I think though
Did you switch to using "auto_direction" ? Can you try to set 1 boundary condition first, then when it works the other ones

This is to help the automated periodic boundary condition detection, which should only see 1 sideset per boundary to pair with another boundary

I see.

Did you switch to using "auto_direction" ? Can you try to set 1 boundary condition first, then when it works the other ones

Yes, I switched to using "auto_direction" and only activated the disp_x for the PBC. The error was the info I gave above. I used mesh-only to show the blocks of it, the blocks are not I want. If I removed the separate block, the subdomains meet my need.

But for both cases, I mentioned above, they got the same error that "Periodic boundary neighbor not found". How can I find out what leads to this error?

I added some checks in the latest version of moose there #29124
They should help debug these setups.
I was able to get auto-direction to set up the periodic BC for one variable. I ll try to take another look over the next few days to make sure the manual option can do it as well, and for the other variables as well
Thank you for being so helpful. I will try the latest version of moose to check the PBCs. Should I turn to the next branch for this test?
if you update tonight, yes. In a few days, this will be in devel

so first issue I met using the new version, the capitalization of the sidesets in the periodic BC isnt right.
I ll see if I can find the actual problem though

second issue is that you forgot to set the variable here
    [./y]
      primary = C1M1-1_PB_left
      secondary = C1M1-1_PB_right
      transform_func = 'tr_x2 tr_y2'
      inv_transform_func = 'itr_x2 itr_y2'
    [../]

I ll add some code to force that
DId you mean to do it? To impose periodicity in every variable?

finally your transformations are incorrect. You had '10' for the offset, but here it should be 0.003464
  [./tr_x2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = x+0.003464
  [../]
  [./tr_y2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = y
  [../]
  [./itr_x2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = x-0.003464
  [../]
  [./itr_y2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = y
  [../]

with these 2 changes, do you get the periodic boundaries working?

node.title: Particle sintering problem
node.bodyText: Hello, dear researchers. I want to use moose to simulate the sintering process of two particles, mainly considering the phase field model, elasticity, etc. May I ask if there are any tutorials or existing cases that I can learn

Hello
There are a few examples of sintering models in the Phase field module
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ElectrochemicalSinteringMaterial.html
see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/GrandPotentialSinteringMaterial.html
which has a list of examples at the bottom of the page
more info on the grand potential model here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/GrandPotentialKernelAction.html

Thank you for your help. In fact, what I want to understand is the simple sintering of two particles. I have seen some papers using MOOSE（for example，https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10853-017-1846-3）, but I do not know how they do it. Can you give me some advice?
This might be in Crow since it's @SudiptaBiswas 's research

node.title: Where can I find more information about the modulus test examples?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello, everyone.
I am learning MOOSE (solid mechanics module) by going through the tutorial examples and test examples. But many examples are given without enough information. So I wonder if they can be found somewhere else. Things like what an example is about, what functional is tested, what result to expect, etc.
Or where can I find another more detailed beginner's tutorial.
Thanks in advance.
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
The test are mostly for continuous integration purposes. A proficient moose user can read them easily. For example and getting started material for solid mechanics, see this page:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/tutorials/introduction/index.html
or navigate from this page before going into object documentation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/index.html

node.title: PorousFlowSink: libMesh error in ThreadedElementLoopBase:Assertion `i < _val.size()' failed.
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Community,
I'm trying to realize a hydro-mechanical coupled simulation using the PorousFlowSink to define boundary conditions:

The boundary condition is defined on one of my model boundaries
The first calculation steps all is fine and Moose works as expected.
The moment the boundary (or parts of it) my PorousFlowSink is active on is re-assinged to an 'inactive' subdomain via a TimedSubdomainModifier, I get the following message in DBG-mode and the model will not converge:

We caught a libMesh error in ThreadedElementLoopBase:Assertion `i < _val.size()' failed.
i = 0
_val.size() = 0

[4] /home/mjg/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh/dense_vector.h, line 422, compiled Nov 16 2024 at 18:32:16

To recover, the solution will fail and then be re-attempted with a reduced time step.

  Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FUNCTION_DOMAIN iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

OPT-mode will work as expected and the model will converge.
I can circumvent this message (and non-convergence) in DBG-mode by deactivating the PorousFlowSink using a TimesEnableControl. But this feels a little unnecessary and adds some complexity to the model I'd like to avoid.
Furthermore, other boundary conditions (e.g. DirichletBC) will not produce any problems even if the boundary (or parts of it) they live on is re-assigned to an 'inactive' subdomain.
I'd tried to understand what exactly is the problem for Moose but did not succeed. It is even unclear to me if this is a problem in Moose or in libmesh.
Could you please comment on this behaviour:

Is this a problem in Moose or in libmesh?
Should Moose avoid this message/error? I am in favour of ‘yes’. But if no, then Moose should also fail to converge in OPT-mode.
If Moose should avoid this message/error: What has to be changed to do so?

Thanks in advance!
Please find a simple test-model below (run-time should be fast)
input-file

This model will fail in DBG-mode. Uncomment the TimesEnableControl to make it converge.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  use_displaced_mesh = false
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
[]

Box1_inactive_name = 'Box1_inactive'
inactive_domain_block_names = '${Box1_inactive_name}'

[Problem]
  solve = true
  kernel_coverage_check = SKIP_LIST
  kernel_coverage_block_list = '${inactive_domain_block_names}'
  material_coverage_check = SKIP_LIST
  material_coverage_block_list = '${inactive_domain_block_names}'
[]

[Mesh]
  [BaseMesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    subdomain_name = 'BaseMesh'
    elem_type = 'HEX8'
    dim = 3
    nx = 6
    ny = 6
    nz = 2
    xmin = -3
    xmax = +3
    ymin = -3
    ymax = +3
    zmin = -2
    zmax = +2
  []

  [Box1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator

Would it be an option to change line 93 from

It's not. We need to get every test function to contribute to the residual. Why the residual is size 0 is a mystery for now
Thanks for sharing an input, we'll investigate
Could it be that the IntegratedBC didn't get the memo that the mesh had changed?

@lindsayad seems the kernels return early from computeQpResidual when they have no vector tags. When is that case relevant?
I see the commit you added this to was for LSC studies. Were you using kernels that dont contribute to the residual then?
It seems to be what's happening to this integrated BC. No vector tags, so local_re gets resized to 0, then crash
EDIT not the case here, there is a tag
so the problem is the residual block which is of size 0, this size ends up being used for _local_re in the TaggingInterface
so I guess the question is, what does it mean to a residual block size of 0 for a variable?
that the dof_indices are of size 0, which sounds like it makes sense if you're on an inactive subdomain

when the boundary condition gets activated, after the subdomain change, is the whole boundary covered by a subdomain on which the variable is defined? Or just part of it / parts of it are next to an inactive subdomain?

I'm not sure I understand the last question. I'll try to answer:
In the example attached in my initial post above, the BC is active from the beginning (t=0). The BC covers all of the model boundary at z=+2 (this boundary is named "front") as shown with the magenta dots in the image below.

At t=0.2 the GlobalSubdomainModifier re-assignes all elements of the subdomain "Box1" shown in red above to an 'inactive' subdomain "Box1_inactive". This is the moment, Moose will show the error reported.

ok this makes sense now!
We need the boundary condition to not be defined on any boundary next to this inactive block anymore.
The easiest way is to modify the boundary at the same time as the block.

We need the boundary condition to not be defined
on any boundary next to this inactive block anymore.
The easiest way is to modify the boundary at the same time as the block.

The input file in the initial post uses a controller on the BC for this purpose (commented out to show the error).
The motivation of this discussion is to avoid those additional controller-blocks in the input file. Other boundary conditions (e.g. DirichletBC) will not produce any problems even if the boundary (or parts of it) they live on is re-assigned to an 'inactive' subdomain. It would be great it we can change the behaviour of IntegratedBC etc. to allow this.

node.title: Why  I use automatic_scaling, Convergence is worse?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, MOOSE developers.
I am going to use SUPG Method in a diffusion-advection problem. when I code this, follwing is the PDE.
$$\rho C \frac{\partial T}{\partial t} - \nabla \cdot (k \nabla T) - q = 0$$
$$\frac{\partial p}{\partial t} + \nabla \cdot [(1 - p) p \vec{v} - \nu \nabla p] = 0$$
$$0 = \rho \cdot \Delta$$
So my Input file is

  displacements = 'disp_x'

node.title: Using the Newton solver for k-epsilon turbulence models
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hello!
I am currently attempting to design a RANS model using the k-epsilon formulation you all have implemented recently, and had a question on the matter.
For my specific purposes, it would be useful to use the Newton-solver to simulate my experiment (I am attempting to do some ROM analysis, and algorithms I have written in the past are based on the Newton update). For non-RANS models (just using simple mass, momentum, and heat transfers), the Newton algorithm seemed to be working, but once I added in TKE and TKED variables and kernels, it gave me the error
For iteration type 'nonlinear': solution state 1 was requested in nl0 but only up to state 0 is available.

And it looks like the error is being given by the INSFVTKESourceSink object. Are Newton capabilities not implemented for the k-epsilon model yet? Or is there a work-around that I have not found?
I've seen the SIMPLE algorithm, and I could probably work with it, but it would be nice to work with what I'm familiar with.
Any ideas on where to go with this?
Thanks!
Charlie
Additional information
No response

And it looks like the error is being given by the INSFVTKESourceSink object. Are Newton capabilities not implemented for the k-epsilon model yet?

They are enabled, though we do not leverage them anywhere so you would be a first-adopter

Or is there a work-around that I have not found?

Did you set the parameters in the problem to request the previous solution? Did you follow the tests for TKE + Newton ?

I did not manually set the parameters in the problem to request the previous solution - I was not aware of that functionality, but I will look into that!
For the tests of TKE + Newton, they all use the Physics block. To build my model, I wanted to start at the basics (I started with just steady-state mass-momentum) and have been building my model up from there, and recently reached the point where RANS was being necessary, and in that, I have not been using the physics block. Does this block work similar to the Modules block, where it is a short-hand for a larger set of input blocks (such that you could completely rebuild it with just blocks in the input file), or is it made deeper in the code?
I was basing my Turbulence models on the channel_ERCOFTAC.i channel-test, and was trying to rework that to use Newton updates.
I am mostly trying to learn how to properly use the Navier-Stokes module right now, so I was avoiding using the larger Module/Physics blocks to have a better handle of what is happening under the hood, and to try and do minor parametric studies to see how much various inputs affect response.

For the tests of TKE + Newton, they all use the Physics block.

once #29177 is merged you ll be able to dump the Physics syntax to regular kernel syntax. It might already work in your case. Try setting (just once) Problem/type=DumpObjectsProblem
Regardless, you can see the parameters of the Problem and executioner block and try to use those

Does this block work similar to the Modules block, where it is a short-hand for a larger set of input blocks (such that you could completely rebuild it with just blocks in the input file), or is it made deeper in the code?

No it's exactly the same as the Modules block, except that there's tons of additional helper and checks that we did not have back when using the Modules block

Okay! the dump wasn't quite working, but it was a mpicxx error, which I haven't set up yet, so that may be on my end. I'll look into that.
I see the source file, so I'll just parse through that in the meantime - since it does work though, I'm all good!
Thank you!
Charlie

node.title: How A Systems Engineer Uses MOOSE & Coreform Cubit
node.bodyText:
I wanted to share with the community one of Coreform's recent webinars that featured Paul Keutelian, owner at Quartermaster Consulting, demonstrating how he performs rapid design iteration and mesh refinement for a rod heater simulation using MOOSE and Coreform Cubit.
You can view the webinar on YouTube here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipkZ9QEaCtw
We hope that webinars like this are helpful for the MOOSE community, so let us know if you what sorts of topics you'd like to see covered in the future!

t = 1s

t = 6

Hi all,
I am also tyring to work sintering in MOOSE, and I am using a very similar input file with AC-CH kernels and free energy(following MOOSE examples and forum). I see the same issue when when the diffusivity(CH mobility) is dependent on the conserved(rho) and non-conserved(eta) phase field variables. The simulation diverges with huge vibrations in the solution of rho. When I simplify the diffusivity to a constant (D=1), the solution is fine and no more vibration in the end.
D dependent on etas and rho, tstep=1

D dependent on etas and rho, tstep=63

input file used attached
input.txt.txt
D=1 constant, tstep=2400

I am suspecting maybe the element order is not high enough, or mesh is not refined enough for the phase field variables? Any help or discussion is welcomed. Thank you.

hello
mesh refinement could just be added with a -r n flag on the command line if you want to try this out
This could also depend on what interpolation functions you are using for the diffusivities. Start with a simple function to debug the issue.
Thank you so much! I will start with maybe a linear interpolation of c and etas with finer mesh and keep trying from there.
@laimaster21 any luck with this approach?

Hi, sorry for the late reply. I think I found the issue, you were right it is with the interpolation of surface diffusion D_surf. The 2018 paper  https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10853-017-1846-3  equation 32 reports D_surf with c(1-c)D_surf in the C-H mobility. It does not converge very well in my simulations. I used (3c^2-2c^3)(1-3c^2-2c^3)D_surf in the mobility and it works fine so far. Mobility constants are picked similar scale to the paper.
